title: Environmental and Scientific Terminology
description: Specialized vocabulary for environmental science and sustainability discourse

items.definition: The capacity to maintain ecological processes and meet present needs without compromising future generations
items.example: Corporate sustainability reports now include environmental, social, and governance metrics.

items.definition: The variety of plant and animal life in a particular habitat or ecosystem
items.example: The Amazon rainforest represents the greatest biodiversity on Earth.
Anthropogenic climate change is driven primarily by greenhouse gas emissions.

items.definition: The action of reducing severity, seriousness, or painfulness of something
items.example: Climate mitigation strategies include transitioning to renewable energy sources.

items.definition: A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment
items.example: Coral reefs are fragile ecosystems that support countless marine species.

items.definition: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; ecological ability to absorb disturbance
items.example: Building climate resilience requires both adaptation and mitigation strategies.

items.definition: The process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon dioxide
items.example: Forest sequestration plays a vital role in removing CO2 from the atmosphere.

items.definition: Capable of being replaced by natural processes in a relatively short time
items.example: Renewable energy sources like solar and wind are key to decarbonization.
